Furthermore, great king!

The rare and profound Dharma is difficult to understand. It is the characteristic of the quiescence of all dharmas, neither grasped nor abandoned, neither aggregated nor dispersed, arising from causes and conditions, without a master.
Because it arises from conditions, it is neither self nor other.
All dharmas are without self-nature, because self-nature is empty, there is nothing to be attained.
Because there is nothing to be attained, all dharmas are quiescent.
The characteristic of quiescence is the characteristic of reality.
Great king!
You should arouse the correct faith and practice and contemplate in this way.
Those who practice in this way are free from all characteristics, neither having something to learn nor nothing to learn, neither attaining nor losing.
Understanding this is correct liberation, and the characteristic of liberation is precisely all dharmas.
The nature of all dharmas is empty, which is the true meaning, and there is no attachment or obstruction, which is called the supreme and rare Dharma.
Furthermore, Your Majesty should know:
The eye faculty is neither defiled nor pure.
Why is it so?
Because the intrinsic nature of the eye faculty is originally true and real;
The ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind faculties are also neither defiled nor pure, because their intrinsic nature is originally true and real.
Your Majesty!
Form is neither defiled nor pure;
Feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are also neither defiled nor pure.
Why is it so?
Because the intrinsic nature of the aggregates is originally true and real.
Up to all dharmas are also like this, neither defiled nor pure, because their intrinsic nature is truly real.
Your Majesty should know:
The mind has no form or characteristics, and is not seen by the eyes.
The mind has no abode, and cannot be found within, without, or in between.
Why is this?
The intrinsic nature of the mind is neither defiled nor pure, and it neither increases nor decreases, nor does it move or change.
Therefore, great king!
You should contemplate in accordance with reality, do not give rise to doubt, and abide in the true Dharma.
Because this mind is true, all dharmas are also like this.
Great king!
It is like empty space, free from all forms and appearances, and also without movement or change.
If someone were to say:
'I can defile empty space with smoke, clouds, dust, and mist.'
Would you believe this?
The king said:
No, it is not.ğŸ”½
Because empty space is without characteristics and cannot be defiled.
The bodhisattva said:
The mind is also like this, originally pure, and not accepting any defilements;
And so are all dharmas, whose intrinsic nature is undefiled.
Furthermore, great king!
All dharmas and the dharma realm are neither identical nor separate, with an intrinsically equal nature, without any distinctions.
If one understands this, then one will have no obstructions or increases or decreases regarding all dharmas.

The king said:
Bodhisattva!

The bodhisattva said:

Up to all dharmas are also like this, in the three times there is no coming, no going, no abiding, no attachment, no entry, no return, free from all conceptual thoughts, not within the reach of knowledge and vision.

up to all dharmas being also like this, with no appearance of anything seen, free from the mind of attachment.

Great King!
As the Buddha said:

In my opinion, the Buddhas, the Tathagatas, skillfully speak of birth and death and nirvana in accordance with skillful means, causing sentient beings to become weary of the suffering of birth and death and seek the bliss of nirvana.

All dharmas are empty and have no self-nature.
The nature of those dharmas is precisely the nature of the dharma realm, within which there is no difference of duality.

I now give rise to right faith and do not give rise to fear.
The Bodhisattva Wonderful Auspiciousness said:

Although you have understood the true Dharma, you still give rise to attachment.

I have now become free from all grasping and will never again give rise to views of characteristics, just as a bodhisattva who has attained forbearance no longer gives rise to thoughts of the three poisons.

I have committed the act of killing, which is extremely frightening. In the future, I will definitely fall into hell.
How can I be saved from this?
At that time, the Bodhisattva saw this man and observed that his faculties and affinities were already mature and suitable for being transformed and liberated.
The Bodhisattva then transformed himself into a person no different from the man, went to his side, and also wept, saying to the man:
I have committed the act of killing, which is extremely frightening. In the future, I will definitely fall into hell.
Upon hearing this, the man immediately said:

Only the World-Honored Buddha has the great skillful means that can save and deliver us. We should now go together to where the Buddha is.
After the transformed person finished speaking, he immediately went ahead.
That person, having seen this, also followed him to where the Buddha was.
When the transformed person arrived at the Buddha's assembly, he bowed his head at the Buddha's feet and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
I have committed the act of killing and am afraid of falling into hell.
I pray that the Buddha, out of compassion, will save and deliver me.
At that time, the World-Honored One praised him, saying:
Excellent, excellent!

Because there is no arising or creation, what do you see in the appearance of sin?
Good man!
The mind does not abide anywhere, it is not within, without, or in between;

The wise should contemplate in this way. One who contemplates in this way will seek the mind in all dharmas but will not be able to attain it.
Why is this?
The intrinsic nature of the mind is precisely the nature of all dharmas. The emptiness of the nature of all dharmas is precisely the true nature.
For this reason, you should not give rise to fear.
